newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Samsung claims world first in 1GB DRAM development.
newsitem.headline: Samsung claims world first in 1GB DRAM development.

text.p: South Korea's Samsung Electronics Co Ltd claimed on Monday it had stolen a march on competitors by developing a "fully working" prototype of a one-gigabit dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chip.
"We are the world's first to succeed in developing the fully working die," company president Lee Yoon-woo told a news conference, adding it was the last step before making an engineering sample.
Officials at Samsung, the world's largest memory chip supplier, said the company would soon start working on samples.
"There were several foreign companies who announced success in developing circuit design for this product. But none of them has come up with a 'fully working die'," Lee said.
Lee said the company spent 220 billion won ($266.7 million) over the past two and a half years in developing a prototype, in which all the 1.07 billion cells fully worked.
He said the development was accomplished through the 0.18-micron-fine "redundancy" processing technology. But no further details were given on the technology.
Samsung, flagship unit of the giant Samsung Group, announced in December 1995 the development of a circuit design on the one-gigabit DRAM chip, which has four times the memory of a 256-megabit chip.
Samsung's major rivals, including NEC Corp and Hitachi Ltd of Japan, have also announced successful developments of circuit designs on the advanced chip.
Lee said the one-gigabit DRAM chip, capable of storing 100,000 double-spaced pages of typewritten text or 16 hours of audio data, were expected to be used commercially in the year 2002 or 2003.
"The global market is expected to reach $70 billion to $80 billion a year by 2005, compared with about $90 billion for the overall memory chip market that year," Lee said.
"We expect to remain in the lead of the world memory product market at least until early in the next century," a senior Samsung official said.
World's leading DRAM makers have said sample shipments of one-gigabit DRAMs will start as early as 1998, but Samsung did not give timetable for its sample shipments.
"An important thing is that we are now ready to make samples in the very near future," said Lee.
He also said the technology accumulated in the development of the "fully working die" prototype would help the company cut production costs for other chips.

But stock market analysts shrugged off the announcement, saying that it was well overshadowed by the fears of shrinking profits in the 16-megabit DRAM chips, which are currently widely used in the global computer industry.
"Investors would prefer to wait until they see commercial samples or any visible impact on the company's earnings from the development," said an analyst at Hyundai Securities.

A glut of supply has dampened the international unit prices of both four- and 16-megabit DRAMs on the global market since early this year, causing Samsung and other major chipmakers to suffer sharp declines in earnings.
Samsung, which saw a whopping 165 percent net profit rise in calendar 1995, suffered a 60 percent drop in net profit for the first half of this year ended in June.
Its turnover rose to 8.71 trillion won in the six-month period this year from 7.06 trillion a year earlier, but net profit shrank to 453.4 billion won from 1.13 trillion in the same 1995 period.
(Conversion: $1 = 825 won)
